awd_abstract_narration:
This project advances knowledge through its contribution to I-Corps Sites Instructors at universities across the nation by creating a consistent training approach to enhance quality of the I-Corps experience among the 99 funded I-Corps Sites.  The I-Corps South Node will leverage its extensive experience training National and Regional Instructors in the lean methodology to minimize inconsistencies among Sites teams' preparation level for participation in a National Cohort. Consistent teaching of the I-Corps methodology across the ecosystem of Teams, Regional and Sites programs will lead to increased intellectual consistency from instructors at all levels. As a result, teams will have more success in the translation between Sites and other programming levels, including Regional cohorts and the Teams program as well as the likelihood for success in advancing the I-Corps concepts into the private sector.  The formation of an Instructor Academy for Sites standardizes the training among Sites instructors, resulting in an increase in consistency among the instruction provided to Sites teams. The proposed pilot project to address and alleviate the inconsistencies in instruction among Sites, thereby increasing translation between the Sites and Teams programs. The Georgia Tech I-Corps South Node and has the potential to establish new norms in both instruction quality and the expectations Sites teams  have before pursuing National I-Corps Teams.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The I-Corps South Sites Instructor Academy was developed to provide a pilot instructor academy session designed to train NSF I-Corps Sites Instructors in the tactical execution of teaching lean startup methodology in the I-Corps fashion in a classroom environment. The formation of a Sites training session provided the opportunity to ensure consistent I-Corps training to the instructors affiliated with these programs. I-Corps South has had success scaling its Instructor Academy program for instructors across the nation, in Puerto Rico, with Mexico’s Council for Science and Technology and with the Science Foundation of Ireland (SFI). The I-Corps South team utilized the existing structure and curriculum to develop the Sites Instructor Academy pilot.

The major activities completed under this award have been the development and execution of a pilot training academy and two follow-on training programs. This first iteration of the Sites Instructor Academy was held in January of 2021 and was scheduled around an I-Corps Teams National Cohort Kickoff event for observation purposes. The goal of the multi-day observation was to provide the Sites instructors with the opportunity to learn from the styles and patterns of national instructors as they engaged with curriculum delivery and with coaching teams. In addition to observing a National Teams Cohort Kickoff event, the participants engaged in a four-day virtual training program. In this program they were provided with Lean Startup content, instruction on how to teach said content, and simulated learning scenarios to give them real time practice with coaching mock team feedback sessions.

In the initial training academy hosted, a total of 26 participants were trained from 17 I-Corps Sites Awarded Institutions. The second iteration, held in October 2021, trained 24 instructors from 15 unique institutions. The third iteration, held in April 2022, trained 21 instructors from 17 unique institutions.

The initial pilot academy was significantly delayed due to complications related to the Covid-19 pandemic. In addition, what was originally intended to be an in-person training event was subsequently converted to a virtual training event to match the decision to facilitate virtual events by the NSF I-Corps Teams program. Due to the importance of providing the participants with the opportunity to observe a National Cohort the initial program was delayed until suitable National I-Corps Teams Cohorts could be identified and coordinated.

The formation of an Instructor Academy for Sites unifies the training among Sites instructors, resulting in an increase in consistency among the instruction provided to Sites teams. Our proposed pilot session was aimed at addressing and alleviating the inconsistencies in instruction among Sites, with the intent to establish new norms in both instruction quality and the expectations Sites teams should have before pursuing I- Corps Teams.

Our pre-survey results (completed by 19 of the 26 participants) show that 73% of participants said that they have a background in teaching the lean startup methodology and/or have experience teaching with the NSF I-Corps program. Participants were asked to judge their familiarity with the lean startup method and key terms on a scale of 0-5, with 0 being no experience or familiarity.

“How Familiar Are You With the Term...” -

  • “Evidence-based Entrepreneurship” ~3
  • “Customer Discovery” ~4
  • “Value Proposition” ~4
  • “Business Thesis” ~3
  • “Radical Candor” ~1
  • “Coach vs. Consult” ~2

The post-survey results show that an understanding of key elements of the lean startup methodology increased, though the sample size was smaller (only 9 of 26 participants completed the post-survey). When asked what they “liked most” about the Sites IA training, 66% of the post-survey participants responded that observing the National cohort, in tandem with the instructor training, was the most valuable aspect of the training experience.
